_decoded_content.name: Mano Libre - The Rapid Hybrid Prosthetic Forearm
_decoded_content.description:
The Mano Libre solves the problem of resource scarcity in prosthetics clinics around the world, especially in the developing world where 80% of amputees live. It was conceptualized, designed, executed, and delivered to a patient in 48 hours by a team of engineers and prosthetists in rural Guatemala.

The Mano Libre:

- is a standarized, cheap forearm piece to be used in a upper extremity prosthesis. It attaches directly to the elbow on the upper end, and directly to the wrist on the lower end

- will drastically reduces the time it takes to construct an upper extremity prosthesis

- uses less than $10 in raw materials to construct, making it much cheaper than the traditional method of fabrication

- is much lighter and therefore easier to manipulate than traditional models

Traditionally, this component is fabricated by creating a cardboard tube to fill with plaster to make a mold of this piece. The mold is modified by a prosthetist before a sheet of plastic is heated and pulled over the mold. The plastic then cools, is cut off of the mold with an air saw, and then ground to size and smoothed.

The Mano Libre solves the problem of resource scarcity in prosthetics clinics around the world, especially in the developing world where 80% of amputees live. It was conceptualized, designed, executed, and delivered to a patient in 48 hours by a team of engineers and prosthetists in rural Guatemala.

The Mano Libre:

  • is a standarized, cheap forearm piece to be used in a upper extremity prosthesis. It attaches directly to the elbow on the upper end, and directly to the wrist on the lower end

  • will drastically reduces the time it takes to construct an upper extremity prosthesis

  • uses less than $10 in raw materials to construct, making it much cheaper than the traditional method of fabrication

  • is much lighter and therefore easier to manipulate than traditional models

Traditionally, this component is fabricated by creating a cardboard tube to fill with plaster to make a mold of this piece. The mold is modified by a prosthetist before a sheet of plastic is heated and pulled over the mold. The plastic then cools, is cut off of the mold with an air saw, and then ground to size and smoothed.
_decoded_content.details:
Summary

The Mano Libre solves the problem of resource scarcity in prosthetics clinics around the world, especially in the developing world where 80% of amputees live. It was conceptualized, designed, executed, and delivered to a patient in 48 hours by a team of engineers and prosthetists in rural Guatemala.

The Mano Libre:

  • is a standarized, cheap forearm piece to be used in a upper extremity prosthesis. It attaches directly to the elbow on the upper end, and directly to the wrist on the lower end

  • will drastically reduces the time it takes to construct an upper extremity prosthesis

  • uses less than $10 in raw materials to construct, making it much cheaper than the traditional method of fabrication

  • is much lighter and therefore easier to manipulate than traditional models

Traditionally, this component is fabricated by creating a cardboard tube to fill with plaster to make a mold of this piece. The mold is modified by a prosthetist before a sheet of plastic is heated and pulled over the mold. The plastic then cools, is cut off of the mold with an air saw, and then ground to size and smoothed.

Print Settings

Rafts:

No

                                            <p class="detail-setting supports"><strong>Supports: </strong>                     <div><p>Yes</p></div>

Resolution:

.1mm

                                            <p class="detail-setting infill"><strong>Infill: </strong>                     <div><p>100%</p></div>

How I Designed This

Design Iterations

            <div><p>Following the shape of the traditional forearm, I first created the tapered tube that would fit both the circumferences of the elbow and the wrist. It was a very simple model. From there, working with prosthetists from various clinics in the US, we learned the added value of a 2.5 inch extension of tubing near the wrist so that the forearm could be fit and cut down to a perfect length for each patient. </p><p>At the elbow cuff location, slots were designed to match the metal saddle extensions from the elbow. Pins were added to fit in the pre-cut holes in the elbow so that the elbow sits inside the printed forearm and locks into place. </p><p>The U-shaped cut was added to the design after the first print was done without it. This cut allows the user full flexion and extension of their prosthetic elbow without hitting the forearm.</p><p>Another thing we decided to edit was the fill density of the print. Due to time constraints, the first print was 20% infill that we fit with a patient and it worked well. However, for heavy lifting or stronger forces, we believe that the time it takes to print the forearm in 100% infill is worth it. For prototyping an arm with the intention of lamination of a final product, a 20% or even 10% infill is sufficient.</p><p>The upwards extensions on both sides of the forearm were added most recently, to allow for attachment of the cable housing running from the upper arm and the harness to the hook. In this design, there are two of these extension tabs so that the arm can be used on either a left or right arm. The unused tab can be cut off of the arm.</p><p>The first design with the pin extension for the cable housing was too weak, so reinforcements were added along the walls of the forearm where it's exposed to the stress of the elbow saddle. </p></div>

data.content:
The Mano Libre solves the problem of resource scarcity in prosthetics clinics around the world, especially in the developing world where 80% of amputees live. It was conceptualized, designed, executed, and delivered to a patient in 48 hours by a team of engineers and prosthetists in rural Guatemala.

The Mano Libre:

  • is a standarized, cheap forearm piece to be used in a upper extremity prosthesis. It attaches directly to the elbow on the upper end, and directly to the wrist on the lower end

  • will drastically reduces the time it takes to construct an upper extremity prosthesis

  • uses less than $10 in raw materials to construct, making it much cheaper than the traditional method of fabrication

  • is much lighter and therefore easier to manipulate than traditional models

Traditionally, this component is fabricated by creating a cardboard tube to fill with plaster to make a mold of this piece. The mold is modified by a prosthetist before a sheet of plastic is heated and pulled over the mold. The plastic then cools, is cut off of the mold with an air saw, and then ground to size and smoothed.

data.title: Design Iterations
data.content:
Following the shape of the traditional forearm, I first created the tapered tube that would fit both the circumferences of the elbow and the wrist. It was a very simple model. From there, working with prosthetists from various clinics in the US, we learned the added value of a 2.5 inch extension of tubing near the wrist so that the forearm could be fit and cut down to a perfect length for each patient.

At the elbow cuff location, slots were designed to match the metal saddle extensions from the elbow. Pins were added to fit in the pre-cut holes in the elbow so that the elbow sits inside the printed forearm and locks into place.

The U-shaped cut was added to the design after the first print was done without it. This cut allows the user full flexion and extension of their prosthetic elbow without hitting the forearm.

Another thing we decided to edit was the fill density of the print. Due to time constraints, the first print was 20% infill that we fit with a patient and it worked well. However, for heavy lifting or stronger forces, we believe that the time it takes to print the forearm in 100% infill is worth it. For prototyping an arm with the intention of lamination of a final product, a 20% or even 10% infill is sufficient.

The upwards extensions on both sides of the forearm were added most recently, to allow for attachment of the cable housing running from the upper arm and the harness to the hook. In this design, there are two of these extension tabs so that the arm can be used on either a left or right arm. The unused tab can be cut off of the arm.

The first design with the pin extension for the cable housing was too weak, so reinforcements were added along the walls of the forearm where it's exposed to the stress of the elbow saddle.
